newsitem.title: USA: S&P rates City of Mayfield, Ky revenue bonds A/A-1.
newsitem.headline: S&P rates City of Mayfield, Ky revenue bonds A/A-1.

text.p: Standard & Poor's on Wednesday said it assigned its single-A'/A-1' rating to the city of Mayfield, Ky.'s $100 million variable rate multi-city lease revenue bonds series 1996 due July 1, 2026, issued for the Kentucky League of Cities Funding Trust Program.
The rating is based on an irrevocable direct pay LOC from PNC Bank N.A. The LOC covers principal plus 60 days' interest at a 15% maximum rate for the initial weekly mode bonds.

The LOC expires on Oct. 31, 1999 unless earlier terminated pursuant to its terms. Proceeds will be used to finance or refinance projects that will be leased to participating government agencies and cities. During the three-year period ending Sept. 1, 1999, subject to the approval of the LOC provider, any originated leases converted to fixed-rate correlative bonds will also be secured by the LOC.

Prior to conversion to correlative fixed-rate bonds or to other longer variable rate modes, an amended LOC will be provided with 210 days' interest coverage. Originated leases may be used to secure fixed-rate supplemental bonds, which will be separately secured and not covered by the LOC.
Standard & Poor's rating does not apply to bonds converted to supplemental bonds.
Holders of weekly mode bonds may tender bonds with appropriate notice. The bonds are subject to mandatory tender on:
-- The interest mode conversion date, including conversion to correlative fixed-rate bonds (holders have the right to retain bonds except in the case of a conversion to supplemental bonds);
-- On a purchase date (interest payment date) for bonds in adjustable rate and money-market modes (holders have the right to retain bonds);
-- On a date that a replacement LOC that adversely affects the rating has been delivered;
-- On the fifth day prior to expiration of the LOC, non-reinstatement of all or a portion of the LOC, or upon receipt of default notice under the LOC.

Bonds in a weekly mode are subject to optional redemption on any business day with appropriate notice. The bonds are subject to extraordinary mandatory redemption on Sept. 1, 1999. Correlative bonds are subject to mandatory redemption pursuant to lease rental payment schedules that conform to the indenture, Standard & Poor's said.
